title: Window.opener fix bypass

profile.name: Phabricator
profile.about: Phabricator is a collection of open source web applications that help software companies build better software.

vulnerability_information:
## Description 
Due to a recent report(https://hackerone.com/reports/306414) a fix was deployed in order to resolve the tabnabbing issue. However by using a line break the fix can be bypassed.

## Steps to reproduce
1) Browse to your Phabricator instance and create a new document.
2) Now paste in the following content 
```
[[ //google.com | aaa ]] 
```
and see that there is indeed a rel="noreferer" tag added by clicking preview and then viewing the DOM tree.
3) Now replace the document with the following content:
```
[[ /
/google.com | aaa ]] 
```
and see that no tag is added.

## Impact

An attacker can abuse this functionality to perform phishing attacks against users
vulnerability_information_html:
Description

Due to a recent report(https://hackerone.com/reports/306414) a fix was deployed in order to resolve the tabnabbing issue. However by using a line break the fix can be bypassed.

Steps to reproduce

1) Browse to your Phabricator instance and create a new document.
2) Now paste in the following content 

[[ //google.com | aaa ]]

and see that there is indeed a rel="noreferer" tag added by clicking preview and then viewing the DOM tree.
3) Now replace the document with the following content:

[[ /
/google.com | aaa ]]

and see that no tag is added.

Impact

An attacker can abuse this functionality to perform phishing attacks against users

activities.message: Forgot to mention the magic word: mongoose.
activities.markdown_message: Forgot to mention the magic word: mongoose.

activities.message:
Thanks. I believe this is fixed by:

https://secure.phabricator.com/D19117
https://secure.phabricator.com/D19118

After these changes, we no longer try to guess whether browsers will interpret a given `<a />` tag as a link to an external site or not, and instead just explicitly add `rel="noreferrer"` to all links with user-controlled targets.

This is less robust in one sense: we must remember to add `rel="noreferrer"` to new user-controlled links. However, I'm not confident we can ever reasonably detect all patterns which browsers will accept as protocol-relative URIs. Beyond backslashes (in #306414) and newline (here), it also seems that tabs are acceptable.

Let me know if you catch any issues with the fix. Thanks for the report!
activities.markdown_message:

After these changes, we no longer try to guess whether browsers will interpret a given <a /> tag as a link to an external site or not, and instead just explicitly add rel="noreferrer" to all links with user-controlled targets.

This is less robust in one sense: we must remember to add rel="noreferrer" to new user-controlled links. However, I'm not confident we can ever reasonably detect all patterns which browsers will accept as protocol-relative URIs. activities.message: In assessing an award for this report, I am primarily considering that tabnabbing is a relatively low-severity attack: tabnabbing is a tool which can help support a phishing attack, but generally only represents a small component of a practical, targeted attack. Additionally, this is very similar to the previous report in #306414.

activities.message: Details are available in the public changelog so this can be disclosed at any time.

activities.message:
That was a pretty fast fix and I can't seem to find a bypass. 
Thanks for the bounty!
